chapter.title: Overview
chapter.para: The XSLT plugin contains facilities to perform XSL Transformations, and evaluate XPath expressions. It also includes an evocable indent XML action.

chapter.title: XSLT Processor
chapter.para: The XSLT Processor allows you to transform a source XML document using a series of XSL stylesheets. XSL and XSLT are W3C-specified standards for XML stylesheets and stylesheet transformations, respectively.
To use the XSLT Processor, select "XSLT Processor" from the Plugins menu. This will dock the XSLT Processor. (Note that you may select where a Plugin is docked from jEdit's Global Options menu.)

Once the XLST Processor has been docked, you may select your source by pressing the button labeled "Select". Next, you may create the list of stylesheets which should be used to transform the source by using the "Add" button (and subsequent dialog). Optionally you may name a file for the result to be saved to by pressing the "Name" button; in the dialog window select a directory, enter a file name and then press the "Open" button (a bit confusing but it will work).

When you're ready, press the "Transform" button. This will perform the appropriate XSL Transformations on the Source document and place the result in a new buffer. (Transformation will start with the stylesheet at the top of the list and proceed to the bottom.) If you entered a result file name, then the new buffer will be saved to a file under this name.

If you want the result of the XSL Transformation to be indented then in your stylesheet add an xslt:output element with an attribute indent set to "yes". In the case of a transformation involving several stylesheets, the xslt:output element only needs to be defined in the final stylesheet. The indent amount is set to 2 spaces per indent level. Currently this setting can only be changed in the XSLT.props file, which is contained in the XSLT.jar file.

For convenience, an action named "Transform" has been bound to the "Transform" button. This allows you to invoke a transformation via a keyboard shortcut or toolbar icon by configuring your Global Options. (The XSLT Processor will have to be docked in order for this binding to work.)

The following improvements should eventually be made to XSLT Processor. (Any volunteers?)
The ability to save the current list of stylesheets under a user defined name. Then the named list of stylesheets could be retrieved when needed for later use.
DTD handling is still somewhat weak. URL-specified DTDs are reloaded on each evaluation, and SYSTEM DTDs are assumed to be in the same directory as the XML file which references them. Ultimately, this should be enhanced to behave more intelligently, as in the XML plugin.
Users should be able to edit the XSLT Processor settings (indent amount) via an XSLT plugin section in global options.
Once an output file has been named for the result via the GUI, the auto-saving of the result buffer can't be turned off. Though maybe this is not a problem.

chapter.title: Indent XML Buffer Action
chapter.para: An action named "Indent XML Buffer" is provided that allows you to indent the contents of the current buffer. This action only works for buffers containing valid XML. You can invoke the indent action via a keyboard shortcut or toolbar icon by configuring your Global Options.

Currently the indent amount is set to 2 spaces per level. Also strip-space (remove whitespace text nodes) is turned on, and normalize-space (remove leading, trailing and consecutive whitespace from text nodes) is turned off. Currently these settings can only be changed in the XSLT.props file, which is contained in the XSLT.jar file.

The following improvements should eventually be made to Indent Action. (Any volunteers?)
Users should be able to edit the Indent XML Buffer settings (indent amount, strip-space and normalize-space) via an XSLT plugin section in in global options.

chapter.title: XPath Tool
chapter.para: The XPath Tool allows you to evaluate XPath expressions on an open XML buffer. XPath is a W3C-specified syntax for addressing portions of an XML document.
To use the XPath Tool, first open a file containing well-formed XML. Then, from the Plugins menu, select "XPath Tool". This will dock the XPath Tool.

Once the XPath Tool has been docked, you may enter your XPath expression into the upper text area (labeled "XPath Expression"). When you press the "Evaluate" button, the expression will be evaluated against the current buffer and the results will be displayed in the lower text area (labeled "Results"). Note that the expression will always be evaluated as if the document root is the "context node".

For convenience, an action named "Evaluate" has been bound to the "Evaluate" button. This allows you to evaluate an expression via a keyboard shortcut or toolbar icon by configuring your Global Options. (The XPath Tool will have to be docked in order for this binding to work.)

The following improvements should eventually be made to XPath Tool. (Any volunteers?)
DTD handling as per XSLT Processor.
When the result of an evaluation is a Node set, it would be nice to have a "Hyper Search" type of result. In other words, each node in the list could be clicked to highlight the relevant portion of the XML doc in the current buffer.
